  5. Columns Panel – this panel helps the user to perform column management of fields in the data table.

SCENARIO 5: Automatic saving of Upload Preview draft

In case of unexpected termination, for example: browser/system shutdown or the user accidentally accesses a different application screen, the upload draft is automatically saved and can be accessed by the user who initiated the upload process.

In this way, the user won’t have to worry about losing the draft that was already corrected in the Upload Preview. A warning message “Upload for this table hasn't been finalized yet. Go to upload preview” will pop-up or Go to -> Upload Preview is enabled in the header as an indication that there’s an existing upload draft.

Once the user chooses any of the upload preview links, user will be redirected to the upload preview tab where draft will be present. In this screen the user is allowed to edit the data to correct the erroneous data.

Note: Once the last erroneous value is edited, the upload will be automatically finalized, and the user will be redirected to Data Management screen.

SCENARIO 6: Locking Mechanism in Upload Preview

Data Management is made more efficient with its locking mechanism feature during the upload process in the Data Management of the same Model Table, editable Query function or any related Queries derived from the same Model Table, for example:

       6A: User A has started an upload process in the Data Management or updating upload draft in Upload Preview and User B attempts to upload a file in the same function, User B will encounter a warning message pop-up “Another user is editing this data. Upload action is not possible now.”

6B: In case that User A will be on idle or is not changing anything in the Upload Preview, an active timer message window “Finalize data upload” will pop-up after 12 minutes of being idle and/or inactive to inform the user of the remaining time (3 minutes) before the draft will be discarded automatically. User A will have two options:

  1. Finalize Upload – this option is equivalent to the Finalize data upload button from the header button finalizing upload and saving all valid data rows.
  2. I need more time – this option allows the user to reset the already calculated idle time, providing an additional 15 minutes before the draft is discarded.

User A will be redirected to the Upload Preview. At this point, uploading of file is not possible for User B.

Note: Upload action will trigger application run type: DATA_IMPRT in the Application log monitor, if the user is still in the Upload Preview, the status will show “Awaiting User Input”. The status will change to Success if the draft is successfully saved or Abort if the upload draft is discarded.

SCENARIO 7: Upload with file formats

Just like in old Show screen, you can upload CSV and XLSX files in the Data Management screen using predefined file formats. This makes managing your data quicker and more accurate, especially when working with different date, time, and number formats.

Previously, in the Show screen, clicking the Upload icon allowed you to select a file from your local, and then a dialog would appear where you could choose the sheet (for XLSX) or specify the file format to be used during the upload.

Now, when you go to the Data Management screen and click Upload, you’ll first be taken to a Select File Format dialog. From here:

  • You can either choose Continue without file format, where upon clicking Continue, you will be redirected to Data Upload screen, where you can choose the predefined formats already existing in the system (same as the ones available in User Preferences).

Note: Always remember that in case Number, Date and Time Formats are incorrect (not the same format as the XLSX/CSV file to be uploaded) the Upload Preview will be triggered, since these formats need to be aligned with the file to be uploaded.

  • You can choose an existing file format from the dropdown (by clicking the arrow next to “File Format”). Once you click Continue, you’ll land on the familiar Data Upload screen, where you can finalize your upload.

Note: The Data Upload UI will also change accordingly, in case the user is uploading a XLSX or CSV file.

Let’s look at some common upload scenarios while using file formats:

  1.  Uploading a CSV with the correct file format 

If your file format settings match the CSV content — great! The upload will complete successfully with no issues.

       2. Uploading a CSV with the wrong file format

If the file format selected in the Data Upload on Data Management screen doesn’t match the data in the CSV to be uploaded, the system will detect it and trigger the Upload Preview screen.

In this scenario let’s say that the thousand and the decimal separator are not matching between the file format in the modeling and the data of the CSV to be uploaded.

Upon uploading the CSV file this will trigger the Upload Preview screen, since the file format in the system do not match the formats used in the file. You’ll be able to see exactly where the mismatches are, so you can correct them in Upload Preview or simply cancel the upload and adjust your file format settings to match the required ones from the file.

Note: Make sure your Field Delimiter, Date, Time, Timestamp Formats and Thousand and Decimal Separators all match what's in your file.

       3. Uploading XLSX with correct file format

If the format settings match the content of your XLSX file, the upload will work seamlessly.

Note: For XLSX files, the Field Delimiter setting in the file format is not taken into consideration.

       4. Uploading XLSX with the wrong file format

If the file format selected in the Data Upload doesn’t match the data in the XLSX to be uploaded, the system will detect it the Upload Preview screen will be triggered.

In this scenario, let’s say that the date format is not matching between the file format in the modeling and the data of the XLSX to be uploaded.

Like what happen when uploading a CSV with incorrect format, the data can be edited in the Upload Preview or cancel the upload and adjust the file format settings to match the required ones from the file.

Note: Always pay attention to the Date and Time Formats applied in the File Formats section in the Modeling. DD/MM/AAAA or yyyy as a date format or hh as time format will not be accepted since this is not supported according to HANA docs. The use of file formats can be applied in the same way in both Pivot mode off and on.

And this is it for this blog post. I hope you enjoyed the new features.

Watch out for new features for the Data Management screen to be released soon.

Stay tuned for more exciting news by following the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: Data Management Screen: Master Data Upload in in Editable Query & Understanding Display Options
entry.content:
Uploading master data values in the Data Management screen can be a smooth process - if you understand how the system handles Display options like ID, description, and the combination of ID and description. Whether you're uploading internal or external master data, small details like duplicate descriptions or Pivot mode ON can make a big difference in how your file is processed.

In this blog post, we’ll walk you through the different upload scenarios and explain how the system behaves in each case, so you can avoid common errors and make your uploads error-free. Let’s dive in!

Master data Display Options in Context Menu

If you've spent some time in the Show screen, you might have noticed a handy setting in the context menu for master data fields within a Query function. It’s called Display, and it lets you choose how master data values are shown — whether it’s just the ID, just the description, or ID and description.

This same flexibility is available in the new Data Management screen as well! Whether your master data is managed internally or pulled from external sources (like Queries), you can customize how it’s displayed to suit your needs — making your data easier to understand and work with.

The image below highlights two ways to work with master data in SAP PaPM Cloud. You can adjust internal master data right from the modeling screen (on the left side) or pull in external master data using queries (left side). Curious to dive deeper on this subject? Check out the blog post SAP PaPM Cloud: Introduction of Query-Based Master Data and Hierarchy for a full breakdown.

If you want to customize how master data appears, just right-click on any master data value within the Query function of the Data Management screen to open the context menu. From there, select Display, and choose one of the available options:

  • ID – The master data ID values are displayed in the screen (option set by default)
  • Description – The set master data descriptions are displayed in the screen
  • ID and Description – The concatenation of both ID and Description master data are displayed together in the screen

Once selected, your data will instantly update based on your choice — and you'll see the new display reflected right away in the screen.

The display setting also applies when you download your data as an XLSX or CSV file. So, whichever option you’ve might selected – ID, Description or ID and Description combined- your downloaded file will reflect the same format.

Note: By default, the Data Management screen will always show ID values for master data. So even if you switch the display to Description or ID and Description, once you refresh the screen, it'll go back to showing just the ID.

Upload Master Data with Different Display Options

Now let’s check how the upload process behaves depending on the display setting you use. We’ll check different scenarios so you can see what to expect.

SCENARIO 1- Uploading using master data IDs in editable Query

This is the most straightforward scenario when trying to upload master data values, either internal or external (Query-based).

As long as the master data values IDs in your file match those in the system, the upload will be successful, and the uploaded data will be reflected on the screen based on your chosen upload method.

SCENARIO 2- Uploading using master data descriptions in editable Query

Let’s now check the scenario where you can upload the master data values set with description.

The system can recognize the descriptions as long as they match the defined master data and the upload will go through just fine.

However, there’s a catch.

If your master data contains duplicate descriptions, things get tricky. For example, if two different IDs (like CHMD11 and CHMD15) share the same description (CHARMD11), the system won’t know which one to use. All the values highlighted in yellow have duplicated descriptions.

Now, in the new Data Management screen, after successful upload, you will receive a warning message for each master data field, indicating that the duplicates may lead to unexpected results, as the system cannot reliably determine the correct ID.

That’s why uploading by description alone is not recommended if you have duplicated descriptions in your master data.

 

SCENARIO 3 – Uploading using master data ID and description combined in editable Query

Here’s where things get interesting.

Previously in Show screen, uploading files that used a combination of ID and description would cause errors—you’d need to manually adjust the data before it could be accepted.

Now with the enhanced Data Management screen this action is possible.

The system can now recognize this combination of ID and description as a valid master data value making the upload process safer, even if you have duplicate descriptions in your master data. This new feature can be used in both internal and external master data.

Note: Just always make sure the ID and description values match exactly with what’s in your master data. If they don’t, the system will trigger validation errors.

If you're using Pivot mode ON on the Data Management screen, the behavior is basically the same as when Pivot mode is OFF. So, whether you’re uploading with ID, description, or combination of both, the same rules apply.

The entries highlighted in red in the image below, represent Nodes—placeholders created to accommodate hierarchical structures. These Nodes impact the Data Management screen when Pivot mode is activated. Please note that uploading Nodes is not allowed, as they are not valid master data values.

In case you have hierarchies applied in on your Data Management screen with Pivot mode ON, and you download that specific display, upon uploading, this will always trigger the Upload Preview screen, since the nodes are not accepted as master data values.

No matter which method you use, always double-check your file against the master data in the system before uploading. Keeping IDs and descriptions aligned will save you from a lot of headaches later!

And this is it.

Thank you so much and keep posted for new blog posts in our tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: Data Management Screen: Managing Analytic Privileges, Fix Selections & Data Slice Locking
entry.content:
In previous blog posts, Data Management screen Part 1/2 and Part 2/2, we showed you the newest enhancements in the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM) application for better user experience regarding the new Data Management screen, focused on the Model Table function perspective.

In this blog post we will highlight the enhancements featuring editable Query function and maximizing its potential when applying Object-Based Authorizations, such as Analytic Privileges, Fix Selections and Data Slice Locking.

Upload and Edit in Editable Query When Analytic Privileges Are Applied

In the blog post “SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud: Analytic Privileges”, we explored a significant feature known as Analytic Privileges. This feature, part of the Object-Based Authorization in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model, enables specific users to have Read and Write access to master data. Users granted with Read Access can view the master data, while those with Write Access can modify the data records associated with it in the Input/Output Activity (editable Query).

In this blog post, we will demonstrate how to utilize the new Data Management screen for uploading data when Analytic Privileges are set.

Prerequisites:

  • Create teams with designated users.
  • Establish a characteristic field with master data values.
  • Assign teams Read and Write Access to the relevant master data values, as illustrated in the example below.

Previously, in Show screen, when users tried to upload a file where Analytic Privileges were applied, even if the user has Write Access privileges to some of the values, the upload will always fail.

In the new Data Management screen blog posts Part 1/2 and Part 2/2, we introduced this revamped screen, highlighting its fresh user interface and exciting new features. One of the standout improvements is the streamlined file upload process, which also affect the upload when Analytic Privileges are applied.

Now, with this new screen enhancement, the users can upload a file (CSV or XLSX) in the Data Management screen, where Analytic Privileges are applied in an editable Query on the Modeling screen.

Let’s check the different scenarios for it:

SCENARIO 1 – Upload of a file (CSV or XLSX) when Analytic Privileges are applied

In this scenario, a user in TEAM 1 team will upload a file in an editable Query, with the upload restricted to values where the user has both Read and Write Access (all the values in Hierarchy Name H1), as well as the values that do not have Read nor Write Access.

Additionally, there are two specific cases where the user has Read Access, but lacks Write Access: CHMD1-TEAM 2 and CHMD6-TEAM 1. This will allow the user to see the data, however, the user will not be able to edit it.

Users can easily monitor their uploads through log messages in the footer and in the logs of Application Monitor screen (only accessible for users with APPLICATION_MONITOR READ and SYSTEM_USER_ALL roles). These provide clear feedback, indicating how many rows were automatically skipped due to non-compliance with the current Analytic Privileges. This means that only (Total – X) rows will be successfully imported, while the X rows that were skipped are those that the user do not have Read/Write Access to it.

The user in TEAM 1 can successfully upload 9 rows and will skip 3 rows (CHMD6, CHDM7 and CHMD8 since these values are assigned to TEAM 2).

However, if a user from TEAM 2 accesses the same editable Query, the displayed data will differ because of the Analytic Privileges assigned to each user. This not only applies to the original data already included in the editable Query (highlighted in green in the image below), but as well to the newly uploaded values (highlighted in yellow). This means that from the 9 rows uploaded from user in TEAM 1, user in TEAM 2 will only see 6 (the ones allowed due to the set Analytic Privileges).

Note: If a user assigned in TEAM 2 team  tries to edit value CHMD1, this will never be possible. The user has Read Access to this value although they don’t have Write Access to edit that value, or to edit other value into CHMD1.

SCENARIO 2- Upload with “Overwrite all existing data with data from file” checked

When importing data into an editable Query with Analytic Privileges applied to a Master Data value, only the data for which the user has the appropriate Analytic Privileges will be modified when using the Overwrite Upload option. This also applies to the overwrite of data in the input Model Table.

The user in TEAM 1, upon uploading in the Editable Query, can see in the log messages that 3 rows were automatically skipped, and 9 rows were successfully uploaded. The values CHMD7 and CHMD8 are not present in the Editable Query because the user in TEAM 1 does not have Read Access for those. And although the user can still see CHMD6 (due to their Read Access), this value is not present from the performed upload (since the user lacks Write Access to perform this action), but instead this value persists from the original data which was not overwritten.

Moreover, the upload overwritten in the editable Query also takes effect in input Model Table. This means, that if a user in TEAM 1 does not have Read nor Write Accesses to CHMD7 or CHMD8 and although has Read Access to CHMD6 but lacks Write Access for it, the upload “Overwrite” option in editable Query will not remove these values in input Model Table (values highlighted in red in the example below).

Upload When Fix Selection Is Applied in Editable Query

The fix selection allows to filter the Query output, and the data is displayed based on the values defined in the selection. This action can be configured for all Characteristic-type fields in the Query Element. To know more about Fix Selection in Query Element, kindly check the Help Portal.

After the fix selection is defined, the editable Query function can be further used in the Process Template and Process Instance in the Input/Output Activity.

SCENARIO 1- Upload of a file (CSV or XLSX) when Fix Selections are applied

After defining the fix selections in the Query Element, save and activate the changes, then choose Data Management in the header and confirm the Query output. In the Data Management screen, choose Upload under the header Upload & Download header section, and after selecting the correct formats in the Data Upload window, choose Confirm.

The upload will be successful and the rows that are not compliant with the fix selections applied will be automatically skipped.

Note: If uploading data to an editable Query function and there is Fix Selection maintained in its Query Elements, only the data associated to the Fix Selection would be replaced when uploading using the “Overwrite” option “SAP PaPM Cloud: What's New as of 2022-09-26?”.

SCENARIO 2 - Upload a file where all rows are skipped

But what happens when a user tries to upload a file where all the rows will be skipped, since they are not compliant with the applied fix selections?

This scenario is not allowed, and therefore an error message will be displayed stating that no rows were inserted as well as the number of rows skipped during the upload.

Upload Without and With Erroneous Data in Editable Query When Data Slice Locking Is Applied

In the blog post titled "SAP PaPM Cloud: What’s New as of 2022-12-19?", we discussed an important feature where users can lock and unlock data slices based on specific combinations of Process Selection characteristic field values within the underlying Model Tables. This functionality is part of the editable Query feature used in the Input/Output Activity on the Process Management screen.

If you're looking to utilize this capability, simply follow the steps outlined below:

On the Process Management screen:

  • Select the values under the process selections.
  • Save the changes.
  • Select the process main task and lock the selected values.

Before in Show screen when Data Slice Locking was applied, the upload process was not possible.

Now, with the new enhancements in Data Management screen, the upload is also possible when Data Slice Locks are applied. To be able to perform this action, simply drag and drop your file into the designated area on the selected Input/Output Activity. Select the appropriate number, date, and time formats (according to the file to be uploaded) and field delimiter (in case of a CSV file), and watch as the upload begins and finishes seamlessly

I will show you now different scenarios where the data slice locking can be applied when uploading data.

 

SCENARIO 1: Upload of a file (CSV or XLSX) when Data Slice Locks are applied

Similar to what is happening to the upload when Analytic Privileges or Fix Selections are applied, the number of rows that were successfully uploaded and the ones that were skipped because they are not compliant with the data slice locking applied can be visualized in the log messages footer.

Note: If you are importing/uploading files to an Input/Output Activity, with the “Overwrite” option selected and Data Slice Locking is maintained in the Process Instance properties, the data associated with the Data Slice Locking will not be replaced.

Upon upload, the data will be updated accordingly in the corresponding editable Query used in the Input/Output Activity on the Modeling screen, as well as the input Model Table.

SCENARIO 2: Upload a file with erroneous data and values not compliant with the Data Slice Lock applied

If the user uploads a file with erroneous values, the Upload Preview screen will be triggered and here you can make necessary edits. After correcting all the erroneous data, the upload draft will be automatically finalized and your data saved in Data Management screen.

Let’s imagine now that while making these edits, one of the values that was corrected turns out to not quite fit with the Data Slice Lock currently in place.

You might have noticed the value highlighted in yellow (the A-value) from the image above. This is not an erroneous value, since is in accordance with the allowed values for this specific field, however, is not compliant with the Data Slice Lock applied.

In this case, two processes for skipping rows during upload due to Data Slice Lock can be implemented:

A- Automatic Skipping: Rows without erroneous data that are automatically skipped if their values do not comply with the current Data Slice Lock.

B- Upload Preview Skipping: Rows containing erroneous data can be edited in the Upload Preview screen and if they do not align with the applied Data Slice Lock, they will be also skipped.

Note: For this scenario, the user can only track these actions and any relevant messages that provides a clear visibility into the upload process, as shown below.

  1. The first highlighted sequence displayed in the picture above, illustrates a scenario where the Upload Preview screen is triggered due to erroneous data that requires editing before the upload can be completed. Notably, a warning message appears indicating that two rows were skipped. These rows were not flagged for erroneous data; rather, they were excluded because they did not comply with the current data slice lock. As a result, these two rows were not included in the Upload Preview.
  2. The second highlighted sequence another warning message is displayed. This time, it informs the user that one uploaded row was skipped due to non-compliance with the current data slice lock. This issue arose when the user edited a value that conflicted with the established compliance rules. Consequently, this row was also omitted from the upload process, resulting in a successful upload of only 5 rows.

Note: When user is trying to download the data where Data Slice Locking is applied, the option “Complete dataset” can be used with or without applying formatting, and the user will be able to easily spot the differences based on the filters applied.

One last thing to keep in mind: everything we’ve covered about uploading with Data Slice Lock also applies to the Model Table that serves as an input function to the editable Query where the Data Slice Lock is applied. So, if you’re uploading data directly to a Model Table and Data Slice Locking is in place, the upload behavior will work just like it does for the editable Query.

And this is it.

Hope that you enjoyed reading our blog post. Stay tuned for more updates and if you like to read previous blog post kindly visit the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Extended Environment Access Level Functionality
entry.content:
Hi Dear Community Members!

Previously in the blogpost SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Introducing the Environment Access Management Screen we introduced you to Environment Access Management (EAM) Screen where administrators can set an environment access level security to control the visibility to their environments by setting them as either “Public” or “Private” which ensures that only authorized users have access to it.

To unlock its full potential, SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud – Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM) is glad to announce the extended environment access level functionality where administrators can now start setting the environment access level from Environment Screen (Main) and Content Management. in this blogpost, I will walk you through the steps on how to do it from Creation, Editing, and even Copying of an environment to setting environment access level when importing a content to your tenant.

Before we proceed, it is important to take note that admin users must have the ENVIRONMENTS_ACCESS_ALL role which will play a crucial part in this extended functionality.

Let’s get started!

In the Environment and Content Management screens, we know that to manage environments your user must have at least the ENVIRONMENTS and CONTENTS role.

But now, if your user has a combined role ENVIRONMENTS_ACCESS_ALL, you will have this additional Access option.

Although this access option is comparable to what is presently available on the EAM screen, you can now define an environment to be either public or private and assign authorized teams from the moment it is created, edited, copied, or imported.

Create a private environment

  1. In the environment screen choose Add button
  2. Choose Environment
  3. In the Add Environment window, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Description
  4. In Access, by default public is chosen in this option but if you switch to Private, as an admin you will be able to choose and assign the Teams that will be authorized to see and access this environment.
  5. Then choose Add

Edit a public environment to private

  1. In the environment screen choose your environment
  2. Choose Edit
  3. In the Edit Environment window, choose the access level as Private  
  4. Choose the Authorized Teams
  5. Then choose Edit

Note: Private environments can also be edited as public, just choose Public in access.

Copy a public environment as private

  1. In the environment screen choose your environment
  2. Choose Add button, then choose Environment from
  3. In the Copy Environment window, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Description
  4. In Access, by default public is chosen in this option but if you switch to Private, as an admin you will be able to choose and assign the Teams that will be authorized to see and access this environment.
  5. Then choose Copy

Note: Private environments can also be copied as another private environment and the admin will have an option to either retain or change the assigned authorized teams.

Now, let’s take a look in Content Management screen. First thing that you will notice is a new column called Access which indicates if an environment in the list is public or private.

Let us understand how import works with this environment access level functionality!

Import a public environment and make it as private

  1. In the Content Management, choose the content that you want to import
  2. Choose Import button
  3. In the Import Environment, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Activate: Yes/No
    4. In the Access, choose Private
    5. Assign the Authorized Teams
  4. Then choose Import as New

Note: Private environments can also be imported as public, just choose Public in access.

But, what if you export a private environment with teams assigned to it? What will happen if you import this environment to a target tenant? Let’s answer that in the next scenarios.

  • Import a private environment with Team existing in both Source and Target tenants
  • Import a private environment with Team existing from Source but not existing in Target tenant

Import a private environment with Team existing in both Source and Target tenants

  1. In the Content Management, choose the content that you want to import
  2. Choose Import button
  3. In the Import Environment, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Activate: Yes/No
    4. In the Access, automatically this will be set as Private
    5. Assign or Unassign the Authorized Teams
  4. Then choose Import as New

Note: In the Authorized Teams, admin will have an option to either retain, change, or add more teams.

Import a private environment with Team existing from Source but not existing in Target tenant

  1. In the Content Management, choose the content that you want to import
  2. Choose Import button
  3. Create Missing Teams: Yes/No
  4. In the Import Environment, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Activate: Yes/No
    4. In the Access, automatically this will be set as Private
    5. Assign or Unassign the Authorized Teams
  5. Then choose Import as New

Note: The system will either create the missing teams if the teams that are currently assigned in the environment that will be imported are present in the target tenant. The administrator must then assign the users in the created team as users are not importable due to different team composition is different tenants. Or, totally not include the team in the import if Create Missing Teams = No.

Now, if you have gone through or already read the blogpost, SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Introducing the Environment Access Management Screen you should already know the conditions and expected result when an environment is created or imported as private which is explained in two (2) different scenarios with Privileged Role Access and Authorized Team Membership Granting Access.

That’s it! I hope the examples provided in this blogpost are able to show you the things that you need to know about the extended Environment Access Level Functionality. Now the only thing left is for you to explore. Till the next new features from SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model. Enjoy!

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2025-09-01?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community members!

We’re excited to share the latest updates in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model. This release introduces new roles, enhanced data management capabilities, and flexible feature toggling to improve your modeling and administrative experience.

 

I. Modeling Screen

We are introducing a new role in the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud – Standard Model for the modeling screen called MODELING_RUN. Similarly with MODELING_READ role, the users with MODELING_RUN will not be able to perform changes in the Modeling screen, but users with this role can activate and run functions and execution activity in the process template level in the Modeling.

Additionally, the users with the MODELING_RUN role can access the Data Management Screen to view data but cannot edit it. The available options include downloading data, working with Layout, and using the Settings section to display the technical fields or toggle Pivot mode on and off.

To use this role, you need to update the instance in BTP with the new JSON code that contains the new role. You can find more information on how to perform this action on the Service Instance - Sample JSON File

After this, the MODELING_RUN role will be available in the Roles tab. Now you can create a role collection and assign it later to a designated use.

For more information, you may check the Role Templates in Standard Model.

 

II. Administration | Settings Screen

Let me walk you through the new section in the Settings screen, the Optional Features Settings! The Optional Features Settings gives administrators a way to activate or deactivate optional features of tenant for the users to explore the new features early in a certain period before the optional features are released globally.

Administrators will be notified through an in-app banner, which will include information about the new feature and a link to the SAP Community blog post, where they can read the published articles about the new features.

 To activate an optional feature:

  1. Go to the Menu > Administration > Settings screen via:
    1. Home page information banner link
    2. Menu > Administration > Settings
  2. Scroll down to Optional Features Settings section, click the toggle button for the feature you want to activate.
  3. Choose Save.

After successfully activating an optional feature/s, all users will receive a notification banner regarding the new available feature/s on their home page, including the SAP Community blog post link. Users can now explore the new activated feature.

Note: To view additional information about the feature, hover the cursor over the info tooltip.

In any case that administrators would want to switch back to the old features, we also have the option to deactivate the optional feature temporarily. At this moment, administrators will also have the chance to provide feedback on the feature.

To deactivate an optional feature:

  1. Go to the Settings screen via Menu > Administration > Settings.
  2. Under Optional Features Settings section, click on the toggle button of the feature you want to deactivate.
  3. After toggling, the system displays a feedback prompt. Choose either Submit Feedback or Skip Feedback to continue.
  4. Choose Save to apply your changes.

Once an optional feature is globally released, it will be automatically removed from the Settings screen.

Note: If no optional features are currently available, administrators will see the following message in the Settings screen

 

III. In-App Notification

There is a new notification method in SAP PaPM Cloud SM, this time it can be found in application level where users will also be notified apart from the email notifications that Performer and Reviewer teams are getting when Submitting, Approving or Submitting, and Initializing an activity or process. This In-App notification can be enabled via:

  1. Menu
  2. User Preferences
  3. Enable or Disable ‘Push Notifications’

After this switch is enabled, users part of Performer or Reviewer will now be notified via the bell icon on the upper-right side of the application.

For more information visit: Notification Settings

 

IV. Environment Screen (main) and Content Management

Another exciting addition in SAP PaPM Cloud SM application is the extended environment access level security which can now be maximized when creating, editing, and copying an environment in Environment Screen and Import any environment in Content Management.

For details you can read the blogpost SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Extended Environment Access Level Functionality.

 

V. Managing Default Data Representation (Modeling and Process Management screens)

SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model modelers and process users can now conveniently set a default data representation or view in their input/output activities in Process Templates and Process Instances so they can immediately see the default view upon viewing input/output data.

To set the default data representation in Modeling and Process Management screens:

  1. In your modeling area, go to your existing Process Template > Input/Output Activity.
  2. In the General properties, scroll down to Default Data Representation section.
  3. Click on the dropdown and select an option:
    1. Pivot Off – If this is chosen, the data will be presented in Pivot Off view by default in Show screen.
    2. Pivot On – If this is chosen, the data will be presented in Pivot On view by default in Show screen.

       

  4. Choose Save to apply the changes.
  5. Choose the Manage Data button to view data.

To set the default data representation in Process Management screen:

  1. In the Process Management screen, go to your existing Process Instance > Input/Output Activity.
  2. In the General properties, scroll down to Default Data Representation section.
  3. Click on the dropdown and select an option:
    1. Pivot Off – If this is chosen, the data will be presented in Pivot Off view by default in Show screen.
    2. Pivot On – If this is chosen, the data will be presented in Pivot On view by default in Show screen.

       

  4. Choose Save to apply the changes.
  5. Choose the Manage Data button to view data.

Note: The default data representation defined from Process Template level will be reflected in the Process Instance input/output activity which can still be updated in the Process Instance level. 

 

VI. Data Management screen 

With the newest update, download options in Pivot ON of Data Management screen have been enhanced. Along with the visible dataset, you can now download the complete dataset, giving you full access to all the data in just one click. The dataset can also be exported in any file format that has been defined in the Modeling screen, giving you full flexibility.

Steps to download the complete dataset:

  1. Open the Data Management screen
  2. Enable Pivot mode
  3. Click the Download button in the header
  4. In the Data Download window, select Complete dataset
  5. (Optional) Choose the desired file format (as defined in Modeling screen)
  6. Click Download for the preferred XLSX or CSV format

Thank you for reading this blog post! We hope these new features enhance your experience with SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model. To explore previous updates, check out the tag PaPMCloudWhatsNew. Stay tuned for future What's New posts!

entry.title: How CO-PA may help each level of Management
entry.content:
When we often hear about CO-PA we often think about complex reports that only finance teams may understand. However, it is one of the most powerful and probably one of the most underutilized report in an organization. Used properly, it can help bridge the gap between numbers and strategy wherein we are turning data into actual business insights.

CO-PA can be utilized by each level of management i.e. top, middle and lower. Below is an illustration on how each level of management can use this report to achieve their own goals.

 

Top-level management:

These are the strategists like CEO, CFO and Directors. Most important for them is to get a birds-eye view of the organization and are more concerned about future long-term strategies rather than daily operations. CO-PA helps answer questions like:

  • How does my profitability look across various regions/ customers/ product line?
  • Which product groups are driving our top-line and bottom-line and which are becoming costs to the company?
  • Which products should I scale up and which should I think about discontinuing?
  • Which market needs more penetration and which ones should I be exiting?
  • What are the true drivers of our profit?

 

Middle-level management:

These are people like zonal sales managers, plant heads etc. These people need on-ground data to plan and monitor targets set by the top-level management. They are also responsible for making top management’s vision a reality by taking into account on-ground challenges. CO-PA may help them to take corrective actions by giving answer to following questions:

  • Is there a sudden spike in material, logistics costs compared to previous period?
  • Are the actuals aligned with plan and standards set?
  • What is the status of contribution margin for each product compared to previous period?

 

Lower-level management:

These are team leaders, supervisors and managers. CO-PA can help them to answer:

  • How is my performance against daily/ weekly targets?
  • Are there any unusual cost trends?
  • What is the contribution margin for same product compared to previous period?

 

The questions I have provided are just an illustrative list. Each company can use CO-PA to build their own strategy and plan and monitor based on it.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model Data Import to SAP Analytics Cloud using RFA JS
entry.content:
We are now familiar with the integration between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM), thanks to the blog posts How SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) pulls data from SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) and How to setup Model View OData.

With this integration and the use of MultiAction in SAC, we can easily perform data calculations in SAP PaPM Cloud SM and reporting processed data in SAC.

In addition, with the integration topic above, SAC provides a Data Import Service that enables users to import master data and facts into an existing SAC model. This API can be called in SAP PaPM Cloud SM by using the Remote Function Adapter JavaScript (RFA JS).

Therefore, even without the usage of MultiAction in SAC, SAP PaPM Cloud SM can perform a data import towards an existing SAC Model.

On this blog post, what I am going to show is how we can utilize the RFA JS to perform a data import to SAC.

Prerequisites

  • You have an existing model in SAC. See Create a New Model.
  • Environment to be used in SAP PaPM Cloud SM. See Environment.
  • Existing OAuth Client to be used in the creation of Destination. See Manage OAuth Clients.
  • Created Destination in SAP BTP. See, How to setup Model View OData.

Procedure

Empty SAC Model

Here’s the SAC Model that we are going to perform a data import. This model is totally empty for us to see the imported data records later from our Run in SAP PaPM Cloud SM.

You can take note of the Model ID above in the URL as it will be used later on our script.

Add new property to your existing destination.

RFA JS can call BTP Destination. Administrators can put additional properties “IsInjectable” set to “true” for us to be able to use this Destination on our RFA JS script.

If this property is not added, then an error will occur that the destination “IsInjectable” property is not set to “true” like the image below:

Modeling setup

To demonstrate how the writing functions when we use RFA JS, I will only use basic data fields.

Model Table Input

The expectation is these data records above will be imported on our empty SAC Model.

Note: All data records for Dimension fields that will be passed to SAC model should be included in the Dimension Table. Data that are not included will be disregarded upon import. For more information, see api/v1/dataimport.

RFA JavaScript configuration

The RFA JS we have created will make the Model Table above as our Input. In addition, all available fields are added on the selection fields.

For more information on other properties, see JavaScript.

We are going to add now the generic script you can copy and paste on your RFA JS in your environment.

/* 
    Mapping of fields from SAC and SAP PaPM Cloud SM. Fields are case sensitive, please ensure it is in the right format same from SAC and your SAP PaPM Cloud SM.
*/
const FIELDS_MAPPING = {
    // 'SAC_FIELD1_NAME': 'PAPM_FIELD1_NAME',
    // 'SAC_FIELD2_NAME': 'PAPM_FIELD2_NAME',
    // 'SAC_FIELD3_NAME': 'PAPM_FIELD3_NAME'
    'Version': 'VERSION',
    'Date': 'DATE',
    'PRODUCT': 'PRODUCT',
    'CUSTOMER': 'CUSTOMER',
    'AMOUNT': 'AMOUNT',
    'QUANTITY': 'QUANTITY'

};
/*
    Fill line below with SAC connection details, as defined in BTP.
*/
// e.g. SACDES
const BTP_DESTINATION_NAME = 'SACDES';
/*
    Fill line below with SAC details
*/
// e.g. Cdgqgo84cv2pmkud7lpl3k6e4p
const SAC_MODEL_NAME = 'Cdgqgo84cv2pmkud7lpl3k6e4p';

/*
    Do not modify lines below.
*/
const { clientId, clientSecret, tokenServiceURL, URL } = getBtpHttpDestination(BTP_DESTINATION_NAME);
const authTokenResponse = fetchSync(`${tokenServiceURL}?grant_type=client_credentials`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': `Basic ${btoa(`${clientId}:${clientSecret}`)}`,
        }
    }
);
if (authTokenResponse.status !== 200) {
    console.error('Error while fetching auth token!', JSON.stringify(authTokenResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while fetching auth token!');
}

const authToken = 'Bearer ' + authTokenResponse.result.access_token;
const csrfResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/csrf`, 'text', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': 'fetch',
            'x-sap-sac-custom-auth': 'true',
        }
    }
);
if (csrfResponse.status !== 200) {
    console.error('Error while fetching CSRF token!', JSON.stringify(authTokenResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while fetching CSRF token!');
}
const xCsrfToken = csrfResponse.headers['x-csrf-token'];
const cookie = csrfResponse.headers['set-cookie'];

const createJobBody = JSON.stringify({ Mapping: FIELDS_MAPPING})
const createJobResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/models/${SAC_MODEL_NAME}/factData`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
            cookie,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body: createJobBody,
        method: 'POST'
    }
);
if (createJobResponse.status !== 201) {
    console.error('Error while creating a job!', JSON.stringify(createJobResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while creating a job!');
}

const jobId = createJobResponse.result.jobID
const dataToExport = scope.data;
const body = JSON.stringify({ 'Data': dataToExport });

const addRowsResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/jobs/${jobId}`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
            cookie,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body,
        method: 'POST'
    }
);
if (addRowsResponse.status !== 201) {
    console.error('Error while adding rows to job!', JSON.stringify(addRowsResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while adding rows to job!');
}

if (addRowsResponse.result.failedNumberRows > 0) {
    console.error('Invalid rows found!', JSON.stringify(addRowsResponse.result));
    throw new Error('Invalid rows found!');
}

const runJobResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/jobs/${jobId}/run`, 'json', {
        headers: {
            'Authorization': authToken,
            'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
            cookie,
            'Content-Type': 'application/json'
        },
        body,
        method: 'POST'
    }
);
if (runJobResponse.status !== 201) {
    console.error('Error while starting job run!', JSON.stringify(runJobResponse));
    throw new Error('Error while starting job run!');
}

const timeoutTime = Date.now() + 20 * 1000;
const interval = 2 * 1000;
while(Date.now() < timeoutTime) {
    Atomics.wait(new Int32Array(new SharedArrayBuffer(4)), 0, 0, interval);
    const jobStatusResponse = fetchSync(`${URL}/api/v1/dataimport/jobs/${jobId}/status`, 'json', {
            headers: {
                'Authorization': authToken,
                'x-csrf-token': xCsrfToken,
                cookie,
                'Content-Type': 'application/json'
            }
        }
    );

    if (jobStatusResponse.status !== 200) {
        console.error('Error while checking job status!', JSON.stringify(jobStatusResponse));
        throw new Error('Error while checking job status!');
    }
    if (jobStatusResponse.result.jobStatus === 'COMPLETED') {
        console.success('SAC Import was successful!');
        break;
    }
    if (jobStatusResponse.result.jobStatus === 'FAILED') {
        console.error('SAC Import was not successful!', JSON.stringify(jobStatusResponse));
        throw new Error('Error during SAC Import!');
    }
}

Disclaimer: This is just a generic script that can be used in RFA JS. In case you have some issues with the syntax, please communicate with your JavaScript expert.

Once the script is added, you may now proceed on the Activation and Run of your RFA JS function. Successful run will show a message log like this:

After the Run of RFA JS, we may now proceed checking our empty SAC Model if the data records are successfully imported.

Data import using the RFA JS from SAP PaPM Cloud SM uses he default method which is Update. In this case, the Run of RFA JS performs an upsert on the target model.

Dimensions in SAC are treated as keys, then If a row in the imported data matches all the dimensions of a row in the target model, that row will be updated. If there is no match from the source row then it will be inserted as a new row.

For more information, see Model Job Settings.

To give an example, let’s say I have updated my data records from my model table input.

Highlighted with Green – these data records will only update our SAC Model in terms of Amount and Quantity. This is expected as it will match the existing data records we have imported earlier from previous step.

Highlighted with Red – since we are using the method Update in our data import from RFA JS, nothing will happen for these three(3) data records as it already exists in our SAC model that uses the dimension

Highlighted with Orange – the dimensions for this data records are all unique. Therefore, this will be inserted as a new row.

Highlighted with Blue – this data records are not available in our Dimension table, then this will be disregarded from our data import.

Fast forward to the Run of RFA JS, here’s the result in our SAC model. The order was changed as it depends on the latest data rows that are recently updated.

As explained above, the data records highlighted with red are not updated as we do not have any changes from our model table input. While we have a new data record which is highlighted with orange as it doesn’t any matches in terms of Dimensions in our SAC Model. Other than that, we have the data records highlighted with green which were updated in terms of AMOUNT and QUANTITY columns.

Lastly, we cannot see the data record highlighted with blue as the PROD0X and CUST0X values are not included on our dimension table for PRODUCT and CUSTOMER fields from our target sac model.

Okay! This is the end of our blog post and I hope I have provided you an information that can be use for your demos or projects when using the SAP PaPM Cloud SM integration with SAC.

You may follow our tag PaPMCloudSMIntegration to see all available blog post discussing integration topics.

See you again on my next blog!

entry.title: Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an essential part of SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC)
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is crucial for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. The capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data is key success criteria. However, many companies struggle with data problems (fragmented information, outdated systems, and the challenge of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI).

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. The second blog post will summarise key arguments why Planning & Analytics (P&A) is an integral part of SAP BDC.

Picture 1: SAP BDC Intelligent Application - Working CapitalThere are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering
  2. Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. SAP PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

SAP BDC is equipped with powerful data management, planning & analytics (P&A), and innovative AI capabilities to tackle all these challenges and P&A is an essential part of SAP BDC. It provides transformative insights, seamless integration, AI augmentation, and enhanced data quality. These capabilities are crucial for effective business decision-making and strategic planning. Here are the key reasons why P&A is vital within SAP BDC:

Picture 2: SAP BDC high level architecture & flows in the context of business steering

  • Transformative Insights: P&A uncovers hidden insights using advanced analytics and planning applications across all lines of business. This capability allows organisations to make informed decisions based on comprehensive data analysis.
  • Seamless Integration: It combines SAP and third-party data to unify diverse data sources, enabling comprehensive analysis and a holistic view of business operations. This integration is crucial for maintaining data consistency and accuracy across the enterprise.
  • AI Augmentation: The integration of business AI, such as SAP’s AI copilot Joule, enhances decision-making by providing augmented insights and predictive capabilities. This helps businesses anticipate future trends and make proactive decisions.
  • Enhanced Data Quality: P&A automatically connects data across the business, ensuring accuracy and accelerating time to insight. This is essential for maintaining high data quality and reliability in business processes.
  • Agile Modelling and Predictive Analysis: Planning & Analytics supports agile data modelling aligned with analytics. It uses AI and machine learning to facilitate predictive analysis and simulation, enabling businesses to adapt quickly to changing conditions and optimise their strategies.
  • End-to-End Visibility: Planning & Analytics offers a 360-degree view of critical business processes with fully-managed, curated data products. This comprehensive visibility and control over operations provide businesses with a clear understanding of their performance.

Picture 3: SAP BDC - AI-powered Live-Planning & Analytics in SAP BDC

Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC, empowering organisations with the tools and insights needed to drive strategic initiatives, improve efficiency, and enhance decision-making across the enterprise.

The usage of Planning & Analytics (P&A) is therefore closely connected to the performance of an organisation and creation of business value through several key mechanisms that enhance decision-making, efficiency, and strategic alignment. Here’s how P&A impacts organisational performance:

  • Real-Time Insights: The ability to access real-time data and insights allows organisations to respond quickly to market changes and operational challenges. This agility is crucial for maintaining competitive advantage and optimising performance, especially in turbulent times like today.
  • Strategic Alignment: By aligning financial and operational plans with strategic objectives, P&A ensures that all parts of the organisation are working towards common goals. This alignment is critical for achieving long-term success and improving overall performance.
  • Data-Driven Decision Making: P&A tools provide a single source of truth for data, reducing the need for manual reconciliation and enabling more accurate and timely decision-making. This shift from manual processes to automated data integration enhances efficiency and reduces errors.
  • Improved Forecasting Accuracy: P&A tools, such as SAP Analytics Cloud, enable organisations to conduct predictive forecasting and scenario planning. This improves the accuracy of financial and operational forecasts, providing a forward-looking view of performance. This allows leaders to react promptly, leading to better resource allocation, strategic planning, and improved performance.
  • Enhanced Collaboration: By integrating planning processes across different departments, such as HR and finance, P&A fosters collaboration and alignment within the organisation. This integration helps create a unified approach to achieving business goals and improves communication across teams.
  • Increased Efficiency: Automation of planning processes reduces the time and effort required for data collection and analysis, allowing employees to focus on higher-value tasks such as strategic analysis and decision-making.

In summary, Planning & Analytics enhances organisational performance by improving forecasting accuracy, fostering collaboration, providing real-time insights, enabling data-driven forward looking decision-making, ensuring strategic alignment, and increasing efficiency. These benefits collectively contribute to a more agile, informed, and strategically aligned organisation.

Do you want to embark on a journey? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

In our next blog post, @Nektarios_Vasileiou33  will take you behind the scenes to unbox the key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC — solutions that help businesses streamline planning, enhance decision-making, and foster cross-department collaboration. By exploring SAP BDC capabilities, you’ll see how they drive more effective enterprise planning and analysis. Get ready for insights that unlock sharper strategies and smarter decisions. Stay tuned!

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2025-10-06?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community members,

Welcome to the latest update from the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model What’s New series! This update brings a fresh set of powerful features and usability enhancements designed to make everyday tasks faster, smarter, and more intuitive.

We’ve introduced conversation history for Joule, giving you a smoother and more personalized experience with improved intelligent assistance. In Content Management, environment locking during import now helps ensure safer and more consistent data handling, while the improvements in teams import and export bring more efficient team management. We’ve also made a few refinements in Modeling Settings to further enhance performance and usability. Finally, to make guidance easier to access, embedded help via SAP Companion is now available right where you need it.

Let’s take a closer look at what’s new and how these updates can make your SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model experience even better.

Report Management | Joule

Great news! You no longer have to worry about losing past conversations. In the Joule panel header, you'll now find a new hamburger menu icon that opens the History sidebar. All your conversations are stored here and are easily accessible.

Regardless of which environment you are in, you will see all your past conversations in the Joule History panel. This allows you to continue your previous conversation in a new environment, ask about content from that environment, and compare it to the previous one. The conversations are private, which means they are visible only to you.

The title for each conversation in the sidebar is generated automatically. Joule utilizes your first message to create a concise and clear title, making it easy to identify the topic of the chat.

Conversations are arranged chronologically, with the most recent ones appearing at the top. The currently active chat is visually highlighted, so you always know where you are.

A new button + New Conversation has been added to the top of the Joule History panel, allowing users to create new chats. You can still use the existing button in the main Joule header as well—both options provide a clean and fresh chat window.

Joule's responses have improved. After each reply, you'll see “quick replies” options, shortcuts that let you continue the conversation without typing long follow-up questions. This speeds up interactions and makes them more intuitive.

Note: Quick replies are available only with the "gpt-4o" AI model, since the "anthropic-claude-3.5-sonnet" model doesn't support follow-up messages.

Another small but important update – the Joule icon has been moved to the header. It's now always visible, even when the Properties panel is open, making it easier to switch between panels.

 

Administration | Content Management

Environment Locking

In one of our previous What’s New updates, we introduced environment locking  during imports in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model to prevent conflicts and ensure data integrity. Building on that, we’ve now enhanced this functionality when using the “Overwrite Environment” option in Content Management, making it even more robust.

Here’s what’s new in this update:

  • When the user starts an import with "Overwrite" option, the system now locks the environment until the process completes.
  • If the user tries to access Data Management, Process Management, Report Management, or Visualize screen while import is running, they’ll see a message: “Environment import in progress.”

To show you how this enhancement works, there are two ways this happens.

  • User A is currently in the Modeling screen and making some changes, then User B starts importing the environment that User A is currently working on.
    User A tries to:
    • Access the Data Management screen or the Show screen.
    • Save changes.
    • Navigate to the Process Management or Report Management application.

      The system displays the message below:
  • User A is currently importing the environment with the “Overwrite Environment” option set to “Yes”.
    User B wants to access the following applications:
    • Modeling application
    • Process Management application from the Environment application
    • Report Management application from the Environment application

      The system displays the same message:

 

Teams Import

We’ve improved how teams and their child teams are handled during environment export and import. If you have assigned teams with child teams to the environment in the Environment Access screen, all those teams, including their child teams, will be exported. However, the teams will be exported as a flat list, meaning they will lose their parent-child structure.

Later, when you upload the Environment, you will have the option to create all teams, both parents and children, and they will be automatically assigned to the environment in the Environment Access screen as individual teams. With this change, no team members will lose access to environments after import.

 

If a parent team includes any obsolete child teams, those obsolete teams will also be exported. During the import process, you will have the option to include these teams. If you decide to include them, they will be treated as regular teams and will not be marked as obsolete, as shown in the previous image for team “Child 3” inside “Parent 2”.

Note: Teams are created without any members. Users must be added to the teams manually.

Administration | Settings

Modeling Settings: Customize RFA Template

Previously, we have released a blogpost introducing the SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model - RFA's field customization feature which initially supported only the following two Remote Function Adapter (RFA) types: Finance General Ledger and Finance General Ledger Items. As of today, we are glad to inform you that SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model now also supports the creation of custom mapping fields for additional RFA types such as:

  • Finance Accounts Payable
  • Finance Accounts Payable Items
  • Finance Accounts Receivable
  • Finance Accounts Receivable Items

For more details, visit Modeling Settings on Help Portal.

 

Introducing In-App Help via SAP Companion

We’re excited to introduce the embedded help content to the SAP Profitability and Performance Management (SAP PaPM) Cloud Standard Model powered by SAP Companion.

SAP Companion brings powerful contextual assistance directly into your workflow. You can access key information about the application without needing to switch to external documentation. For more detailed information and step-by-step procedures, the SAP Help Portal remains the primary source.

So far, SAP Companion support has been rolled out for the following applications:

  • Environments
  • Modeling
  • Process Management

Other applications will be supported soon, further expanding in-app support across the platform.

To learn more about different functionalities of the abovementioned applications while inside the app itself, here’s what you need to do:

  1. Navigate to any of the supported apps, for example, Modeling.
  2. Choose the "?" icon in the top-right corner of the header toolbar.
    This action opens the in-app help overlay on the right-hand side of the screen.

  3. Use the search bar inside the in-app help panel to quickly search for help topics or explore them in the list.
  4. When you hover over a specific help topic from the list, the system points you to the UI element for which the help topic is created. Once you choose the topic, the system displays a more detailed description of the selected topic.

     

    You can also do it the other way around – choose the “?” icon next to a UI element to open the detailed help topic that describes it.

     

Note:
• SAP PaPM Standard Model currently does not include guided tours. For now, we offer static help and searchable documentation within supported applications.
• Currently, in-app help is available only in the English language.

That's it for this update! 

We hope these new features and enhancements make your experience with SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model even better. To catch up on earlier releases, visit our PaPMCloudWhatsNew tag.

Stay tuned — more exciting updates are on the way!

entry.title: Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/ BW-IP in SAP BDC
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @IsabelWichmann and @irinasheftelevich 

Financial Planner´s Overview page in SAP Analytics Cloud

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions. As an evolution of our industry-leading data, planning, and analytics solutions, SAP Business Data Cloud brings together SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse with a unified experience that delivers transformational insights across all lines of business. 

To fully leverage benefits of SAP BDC in the Planning and Analytics area, it is worth to consider modernizing the Planning engine.  SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is the component that delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience (The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The ... - SAP Community).

But how to get there? For those customers who are searching for a new planning engine the situation is clear. SAC is the clear strategic direction for the planning processes and xP&A. For those customers who are now using an SAP BW based planning engine like SAP BPC or BW-IP the path can be not as straightforward, so we are recommending evaluating the possible ways to start with SAP BDC as the future-state landscape.

SAP BPC PLANNING SCENARIOS WITHIN SAP BDC

There are three scenarios how you can go forward with SAP Business Planning and Consolidation (SAP BPC) as part of SAP BDC.

Based on insights from the original SAP blog on moving from SAP BPC to SAC, we would like to refresh and update scenarios of moving from SAP BPC —into the world of SAP BDC and SAC.

SCENARIO 1: MOVE

Picture 1: Moving to SAC planning at your own pace

Target Landscape: SAC Planning + BDC as the data foundation

This is the option where planning use cases would be completely moved from SAP BPC into SAC. In this case we talk about re-implementation, but you can still reuse some of the things that you have created. For example, you could build a SAC planning model based on the query that is coming from your SAP BPC (embedded model, running on the SAP BW system). That way all relevant dimensions (including its members and hierarchies) could be recreated quite easily. 

What´s new with SAP BDC?

  1. Seamless planning, links SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with SAP Datasphere so that SAC model data (facts & master data) can be stored directly in Datasphere. This reduces data duplication, ensures real-time availability, and allows further processing and extension via Datasphere’s capabilities. ( Seamless planning between SAP Analytics Cloud and ... - SAP Community )
  2. Part of BW modernisation process. SAP Analytics cloud can replace SAP BPC and BW-IP, become the new modern planning engine and reduce dependency on SAP BW. It can help to shrink BW and together with SAP Profitability and Performance management solution and Datasphere can provide a foundation for an End-to-End enterprise performance management process.

SCENARIO 2: COMPLEMENT (=LIVE Planning)

Picture 2: Live Planning

 

In this scenario we are using SAC as a planning/forecasting data entry UX and as well for data analysis (variance analysis in reports and dashboards for example). In other words, users enter data via the SAC data entry form, and the data is being persisted directly in the SAP BPC embedded planning model. No data is being stored in SAC whatsoever. This scenario allows to:

  • Retain existing BPC / BW-IP models
  • Provide attractive & powerful UX to end users for:
    • Data entry
    • Analysis
    • Mobile iOS / Android apps (analysis only)
  • Use SAC Catalog for unified access to all content

What´s new with SAP BDC?

SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, being a front end to existing SAP BPC embedded models and planning logic.

SCENARIO 3: ADD (Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans)

Picture 3: Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans

In this scenario, we can build new functional plans on top of SAP BPC with SAC and then we provide integration (data is replicated in both directions between SAP BPC and SAC). A simple example of such integration could be to bring an initial version of sales forecast from SAP BPC model into SAC model (model – dimensions & measures; with data is being replicated from SAP BPC into SAC). In the next step predictive time series forecasting would be applied on top of forecast data stored in SAC model. If needed, users could perform some manual adjustments or allocations and when done the updated forecast would be replicated back to SAP BPC model.

What´s new with SAP BDC?

As with Live scenario, SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing your data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, not only as front-end, but also as a planning engine, allowing phased transition into strategic solution.

For scenario 2+3 withing SAP BDC: BPC should be moved into BPC PCE of SAP BDC architecture.  This move is supported for BPC NetWeaver as well as BPC on BW/4HANA. See picture below:

Picture 4: Migration of SAP BPC versions to SAP BDC

 

BUT WHY MAKE THIS MOVE?

There are several strategic and technical benefits of SAP BPC PCE in SAP Business Data Cloud:

Strategic Benefits

  • Fully aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Follow the clean core principle: reduce custom extensions management costs
  • Application and technical operations from one vendor
  • Mainstream maintenance until 2030 for SAP BPC 10.1 and 2040 for SAP BPC 11  (BPC/4HANA)

Technical Benefits

  • Support for hybrid planning with both SAP BPC and SAC
  • Scalable platform
  • Continue to leverage SAP BW capabilities

FINAL THOUGHT

SAC/SAP BDC emerging as the new standard, now is the time to choose your path forward. Whether you go all-in on SAC, transition gradually via SAP BW PCE on SAP BDC, or start with seamless integration — SAP Business Data Cloud ensures your planning is built on a trusted, unified data foundation.

Would like to know more?

Check out the BPC MOVE blog series and this further information to learn more about the transition from SAP BPC to SAP Analytics Cloud:

  • Enabling BPC Runtime-license: https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3150518The SAP Note 2969947provides you the latest information of the supported and unsupported planning functionalities when using an SAC Model based on a BPC Live connection.
  • Easily transition from BPC to SAC-P: https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/cloud-analytics/move-planning.html
  • SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard Migration guide

Ready to take the next step?

Start your cloud migration journey. Contact us at movebpc@sap.com to learn more about using SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning to migrate your SAP BPC investment to the Cloud and accelerate your business & financial transformation.

Please check out also SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard and BPC Embedded Migration guide (two migration guides pdfs).

(Fairly) new to SAP Analytics Cloud?

Find out how to apply the basics of modelling, planning, analysing and administration with SAP’s free learning resources on SAP Analytics Cloud. The learning journey is designed for business users who want to upskill and boost their careers. Check out even more role-based learning resources and opportunities to get certified in one place on SAP Learning site.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: What’s New as of 2025.09.01?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

Here comes some exciting updates to SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud – Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM).  In this post, I will walk you through the newest features and enhancements in SAP PaPM Cloud UM.

Let’s dive in.

Manage Environments

New “Validate” button in Manage Environments

To help modelers catch issues before activation, we’ve introduced a "Validate" action in the Manage Environments screen. 

  • Available for saved versions only 
  • Validates the entire model to check consistency 
  • Compiles the entire model to ensure all formulas and expressions are correct 
  • Starts immediately when you click Validate, and progress can be tracked via notifications and the event log 

This helps reduce activation errors by ensuring your environment is as clean and consistent as possible during design time.
